awd_titl_txt: Latent-heat based measurements of the melting curve of iron to the pressure of Earth’s inner core boundary
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

The Earth’s core is a massive ball of metal located 3000 km beneath our feet. Improved knowledge of its basic properties will help Earth scientists better understand the way heat and material move inside the solid Earth’s many layers (inner core, outer core, mantle, and crust). For example, motion of liquid metal in the outer core generates a powerful magnetic field that shields life at the surface from harmful radiation, but the magnitude of forces driving the motion are uncertain. Another example is that heat from the outer core might melt some minerals in the rocks at the base of the mantle, but the amount of heat flow and the temperature at the base of the mantle are unknown. One notable reason for these uncertainties is that a basic fact about the Earth’s core remains highly uncertain: its temperature. The best way to infer the core temperature relies on a simple idea.  The liquid outer core, which is mostly iron, freezes onto the solid inner core as the Earth cools, meaning the temperature at the liquid-solid interface is the freezing temperature, or equivalently the melting temperature, of the mostly iron liquid material. Hence, the starting point for understanding the core’s temperature, and its effect on the entire Earth, is to accurately determine the melting temperature of iron when subjected to the enormous pressure that exists at the inner core-outer core boundary: 3.3 million atmospheres. The upcoming project aims to accurately determine this crucial temperature by using a new type of laboratory measurement. In addition to these scientific impacts, the project will engage undergraduate students, and benefit physicists and materials scientists studying high-pressure phase transitions that involve entropy changes - from magnetic transitions, to superconducting transitions, to melting. The team will also publish the sample preparation details in the video journal JoVE to clearly disseminate their methods to a wide audience. 

Experiments will be performed to identify the absorption of latent heat while samples of iron and iron-sulfide are rapidly heated. The samples will be compressed in diamond anvil cells to pressures as high as 3.3 million atmospheres, and heated with short pulses of electricity that flow through the samples. This pulsed Joule heating procedure allows latent heat detection by limiting the amount of heat escaping from samples, and also limits chemical reactions by restricting the total time during which the sample is molten to roughly 1 to 100 microseconds. The project aims to (a) dramatically improve the accuracy of the melting temperature data for iron up to 3.3 million atmospheres by achieving plus/minus 50 K accuracy up to approximately 1 million atmospheres and plus/minus 200 K accuracy up to 3.3 million atmospheres, (b) to prove that the latent-heat technique can be extended to partial melting of iron alloys by measuring the solidus temperature of Fe(0.9)S(0.1) up to 1 million atmospheres with plus/minus 50 K accuracy, and (c) assimilate the new measurements into models of Earth core adiabats and hydrodynamic models of magnetic field formation and evolution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The main scientific goal of this project was to better understand the thermal history of Earth's core by developing and using a new latent-heat based method of measuring melting curves of iron and its alloys at high pressures in diamond anvil cells.  The main broader impact goals were to train and mentor undergraduates, and to transfer technology to other experimentalists. 

To achieve the science goal, we developed new equipment, prepared high pressure sample chambers using precise control over shape and size of fabricated samples, and measured the melting curve of iron, the partial melting of iron carbide, and the electrical resistivity of iron up to pressures and temperatures mimicking Earth's outer core. The new pieces of experimental equipment are: (1) a very fast temperature measurement system that achieves 0.3 microsecond time resolution at temperature as low as 2000 K [Geballe et al., 2024a], (2) a powerful pulse amplifier to drive up to 200 amps of electricity through our high pressure metal samples [Geballe et al., 2024b], and (3) a less powerful, more transportable pulse amplifier to drive up to 40 amps of electricity through our samples while probing them with X-rays at the Advanced Photon Source at Argonne National Laboratory [Geballe et al., in prep]. With the new equipment commissioned, we then used a new method of preparing iron samples [Geballe et al., 2024c], and finally measured two key material properties while heating -- melting temperature and electrical resistivity for iron, as well as the partial melting of iron carbide. These key results, along with their integration into models of Earth's core temperature profile and core-to-mantle heat flux, are in preparation for publication [Geballe et al. in prep; Miozzi et al. in prep]. Our new melting curve for iron at pressure up to 200 GPa extrapolates to a melting temperature at the inner core boundary on the lower end of all previous estimates. We are currently working on fabrication techniques to extend measurements to > 200 GPa.

The broader impacts of our work were achieved by training two undergraduates and two postdocs in our cutting-edge pulsed heating techniques, and sharing technology through detailed technical publications, as well as collaborations, conference presentations, and technical discussions with beamline scientists from the Advanced Photon Source. This award supported two undergraduates as part of the SURI summer research internship program at Carnegie, giving them early exposure to hands-on research, including experiences in laboratory work, data analysis, python scripting, and presentation of results. Their summer work led to an oral presentation at the APS March meeting by one undergraduate [Anto and Geballe, 2023], as well as co-authorship on one publication [Geballe et al., 2024a]. This award also funded the in-house technical development work, melting experiments, and follow-up synchrotron measurements for two postdocs using the pulsed Joule heating technique. Finally, through ongoing collaborations with beamline scientists at the Advanced Photon Source (APS), we continue to transfer the new technologies we developed. We integrated our electrical heating and resistance equipment into the laser-heating and X-ray diffraction setup at the APS Sector-16 during synchrotron beamtimes, and communicated technical details to APS staff and users during beamtime, the 2024 APS user meeting, and the 2024 AGU meeting.

 

References:

Geballe et al., 2024a, Rev. Sci. Instruments, 95, 023905, ​​doi.org/10.1063/5.0171214

Geballe et al., 2024b, Rev. Sci. Instrum., 95, 053902, doi.org/10.1063/5.0171213

Geballe et al., 2024c, J. Appl. Phys., 135, 095903, doi.org/10.1063/5.0184911

Anto and Geballe, 2023, "Accuracy and precision of a new microsecond-timescale temperature diagnostic for pulsed-heated diamond anvil cells." Oral presentation at APS March Meeting 2023, Las Vegas, NV.
